Yea, might've been a lot of wishful thinking on my part...

I want somethin=
g that learns without a fitness function in mind. It
basically learns a mod=
el of the world that it's in.

In my mind, this algorithm would use localiz=
ed learning rules, and grow
neurons/connections in an organic manner (like =
NEAT but the connections are
added as the brain experiences the world).

Th=
e closest thing I know of is George Hinton's restricted boltzmann machine,
=
but it doesn't really grow organically -- network structure has to be
pre-d=
efined, and also has to be layered.

Richard Gong

On Sun, Nov 29, 2009 at =
2:07 AM, Jeff Haynes <feedyurhed@...> wrote:

>
>
> I think you faile=
d to grasp what David was saying.  Evolution is not a
> learning algorithm =
in the traditional sense.  However, it is how the
> topography of the brain=
 was created in the first place.  If you're looking
> simply for learning a=
lgorithms I suggest you look into any of a great number
> of resources avai=
lable for training neural networks.  As David pointed out,
> much of the wo=
rk to date represents a radical simplification of biological
> systems.  If=
 you're looking for something that closely mimics biology you
> might look =
at work that has been done in modeling a single neuron.  That's
> probably =
almost as good as it gets for the time being.
>
> - Jeff
>
>

29, 2009 at 1:26 AM, Richard Gong <gongrichard@...>wrote:

Evolution is not how biological neural networks learn. Are there any

jects (similar in scope/usability to NEAT) that are more faithful to

logy?

m>
>>
>>
>> > Are there any coding projects similar to NEAT, in its general=
ized
>> > ability, but more like the brain's "live" learning?
>>
>> No one =
knows in detail how learning works in the brain.  We don't know
>> how most=
 things are represented, or how those representations get
>> updated.  All =
we have right now are highly simplified models at various
>> levels of abst=
raction, but we know that these are inadequate.
>>
>> Don't be misled by co=
mputer scientists who give simple learning
>> mechanisms fancy biological n=
ames, like "neural network" or "genetic
>> algorithm".  These are highly si=
mplified and abstract mathematical
>> constructs compared to the complicate=
d and messy biological phenomena
>> they are named after.  It's like the di=
fference between the hypothetical
>> canonball's simple 1D trajectory in a =
vacuum, vs. a real world
>> knuckleball whose spin and trajectory can only =
be explained using vector
>> calculus and fluid dynamics.
>>
>> So to answe=
r your original question: no, we don't have a general purpose
>> learning r=
ule that works like the brain, because we don't understand how
>> the brain=
 works.
>>
>> And although brains have very powerful learning algorithms, t=
hey also
>> have a lot of built-in structure that is present from birth.  M=
ost
>> machine learning algorithms start out with zero weights, or initial
=
>> random weights, not the incredibly detailed structure produced by our
>>=
 genes through the process of fetal development.  So don't think that
>> so=
me simple learning algorithm is going to provide the "magic bullet"
>> that=
 produces intelligent machines.  It's not going to be that easy.  It
>> too=
k evolution a long time to come up with the structure of the
>> mammalian b=
rain.  And it's going to take us another century or two to
>> figure out ho=
w it works.
>>
>> -- Dr. David S. Touretzky
>>   Research Professor

mputer Science Department &

> --
> ...imagine a puddle waking up one morning and =
thinking, 'This is an
> interesting world I find myself in, an interesting =
hole I find myself in,
> fits me rather neatly, doesn't it? In fact it fits=
 me staggeringly well,
> must have been made to have me in it!' This is suc=
h a powerful idea that as
> the sun rises in the sky and the air heats up a=
nd as, gradually, the puddle
> gets smaller and smaller, it's still frantic=
ally hanging on to the notion
> that everything's going to be alright, beca=
use this world was meant to have
> him in it, was built to have him in it; =
so the moment he disappears catches
> him rather by surprise. I think this =
may be something we need to be on the
> watch out for.
>
> -- Douglas Adams=

t something that learns without a fitness function in mind. It basically le=
arns a model of the world that it's in.<br><br>In

hm would use localized learning rules, and grow
neurons/connections in an o=
rganic manner (like NEAT but the connections

nces the world).<br>

 restricted boltzmann

- network structure
has to be pre-defined, and also has to be layered.<br><=

      <p>I think you failed to grasp what David was saying. =
=A0Evolution is not a learning algorithm in the traditional sense. =A0Howev=
er, it is how the topography of the brain was created in the first place. =
=A0If you're looking simply for learning algorithms I suggest you look =
into any of a great number of resources available for training neural netwo=
rks. =A0As David pointed out, much of the work to date represents a radical=
 simplification of biological systems. =A0If you're looking for somethi=
ng that closely mimics biology you might look at work that has been done in=
 modeling a single neuron. =A0That's probably almost as good as it gets=
 for the time being.</p>
<div>
<br></div><div>- Jeff</div><div><div><div></=

</div>No one knows in detail how =
learning works in the brain. =A0We don't know<br>
how most things are r=
epresented, or how those representations get<br>
updated. =A0All we have ri=
ght now are highly simplified models at various<br>
levels of abstraction, =
but we know that these are inadequate.<br>
<br>
Don't be misled by comp=
uter scientists who give simple learning<br>
mechanisms fancy biological na=
mes, like "neural network" or "genetic<br>
algorithm". =
=A0These are highly simplified and abstract mathematical<br>
constructs com=
pared to the complicated and messy biological phenomena<br>
they are named =
after. =A0It's like the difference between the hypothetical<br>
canonba=
ll's simple 1D trajectory in a vacuum, vs. a real world<br>
knuckleball=
 whose spin and trajectory can only be explained using vector<br>
calculus =
and fluid dynamics.<br>
<br>
So to answer your original question: no, we do=
n't have a general purpose<br>
learning rule that works like the brain,=
 because we don't understand how<br>
the brain works.<br>
<br>
And alth=
ough brains have very powerful learning algorithms, they also<br>
have a lo=
t of built-in structure that is present from birth. =A0Most<br>
machine lea=
rning algorithms start out with zero weights, or initial<br>
random weights=
, not the incredibly detailed structure produced by our<br>
genes through t=
he process of fetal development. =A0So don't think that<br>
some simple=
 learning algorithm is going to provide the "magic bullet"<br>
th=
at produces intelligent machines. =A0It's not going to be that easy. =
=A0It<br>
took evolution a long time to come up with the structure of the<b=
r>
mammalian brain. =A0And it's going to take us another century or two=
 to<br>
figure out how it works.<br>
